Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and I’m sitting on my bed, phone in hand, staring at the blinking cursor in my chat with Mom. She’s sent a message: “How’s your weekend, sweetie?” I know she expects a real conversation, not just a quick “I’m fine.” I start typing, then stop, feeling guilty for not calling her last night like I promised. Just as I’m about to reply, I hear voices in the hallway—my new neighbors. I remember the little cake I baked, hoping to make a good impression. I grab it and head to the door, heart pounding. I want to be the friendly neighbor everyone likes, but my phone buzzes again—Mom, asking if I’m okay. I hesitate, torn between stepping out to greet the neighbors and sitting down to call my mom. Both expect me to be present, to show I care. I stand in the doorway, cake in one hand, phone in the other, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which to choose first.
